adding reviewers that have been involved in similar commits in the past

I commented this elsewhere, but this function has been re-engineered and modified so many times, in so many different forks, that I'd like to keep a representation of the "old way" and just have modes we can run this in.

It seems like every time we modify this function, we break someone in some unknown way.  I realize this is directly enumerating hardware, and all hardware acts differently, so aside from being able to set the old behavior, I don't know how we test changes like this.

Lets add a meson option for "16 bit detect mode", and give the modes names of 1, 2, 3, then in code, we can document how each detect mode operates.
i don't see condition for this to return std::nullopt now. Probably still want to cover "no device" or failed to detect case.
It'd  be better to use named descriptive options, with a choices list to restrict it.
Looks like you still need to be added into a CLA and/or the nvidia ci-authorized group?
There is still the 'choices' array that can restrict the values to just the 2.  See https://mesonbuild.com/Build-options.html

Would the codes implicitly restrict/limit the choices to just 2 enough?

With meson option array "choices"/"values", extra codes would be needed in meson.build + codes to parse the array and detect error for the bad usages:

option('fru-device-16bitdetectmode', type : 'array', choices : ['MODE_1', 'MODE_2'], value : ['MODE_1') 

-Dfru-device-16bitdetectmode=   or
-Dfru-device-16bitdetectmode=[]  or
-Dfru-device-16bitdetectmode=['MODE_1', 'MODE_2']
dont we need address for mode1?
Maintaining the same logic as current code (mode_1) by calling isDevice16Bit() without address

I feel like some of the mode 2 comments could stand to be simplified, and have the proposal discussion moved into gerrit and out of the source. 

I don't know enough to comment on the mode2 changes directly, but the rest seems to make sense.
I have no problem to remove them from source code since I already put them in commit message. What do other reviewers think?
In the interest of making it easy for people to know which one to use, how about a new small doc in the docs dir, with a link to it from the main readme?
Just upload new patch with a new small doc and add a link in the main readme as suggested. Please review.

Alright- so isDevice16BitMode1() does line-for-line what isDevice16Bit() did previously. Seems to makes sense.

I personally am a big fan of the added comments explaining what's going on here.

I personally like the comment explanations for mode 1 and mode 2, but I feel like some of the comment below veers into 'design document' (see openbmc/docs/designs territory -- mainly the stuff about proposals and quoting parts of spec docs for justifications. I'm not sure if this is a complex enough change to full-on require a design document to be approved, though.

I suspect the in-source comment could be simplified to treat this as a done-deal, then cut/paste any justifications/points for discussion into a gerrit comment, or in-line gerrit comment for any further discussion needed.

(That said, I don't know enough about operations being done in the 2nd half of this commit to have any complaints about them, and the top half looks good to me :)
maybe now you could just have a comment about referring to your new doc and then wouldn't need all of this here.

Q: what was the NOLINT here fixing an issue about? Was the tool offering build-breaking suggestions?

I understand that it's preferred to avoid using NOLINT where possible (but it's not a hard rule).

Ah. I see - this line, and lines 381-383 are doing the same as what's done in the existing readData() function. That seems to make sense then.

(I still wonder what kind of problem the NOLINT it covering, but that's probably for someone else who's already worked around there on fru_device to worry about :)

The `NOLINT` tells you directly: It's triggering on the `reinterpret_cast<>()`, because the C++ core guidelines ban use of `reinterpret_cast<>()`, and this lint is enabled in the clang-tidy config.

https://isocpp.github.io/CppCoreGuidelines/CppCoreGuidelines#Pro-type-reinterpretcast

Is this supposed to be a markdown table?  If so, the backticks are preventing it from rendering.

If not, it's kinda tough to read with the wrap: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/entity-manager/+/7cd0504fa727f7533e166145a6d1c1d2b12c1e6c/docs/address_size_detection_modes.md

Hmm, https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/entity-manager/+/5d19886235e51084ac9a54b6243a605c0fba4ebd is still showing it wrapping.  Hopefully that's just a gerrit markdown thing and not github.

This is the commit message. It's git's requirement to cut off at <80
The document itself is good

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/entity-manager/+/5d19886235e51084ac9a54b6243a605c0fba4ebd/docs/address_size_detection_modes.md
+1 from me, i'll give it a few more days to see if anyone else reviews.
Can we move forward and merge this? We have no further review/comment after waiting for several weeks.
Re-adding my +1 to help bring attention to it:)
